Brian (who was immune from the curse because he is never sober) says, "I need a drink!" and the film ends.  While this film is nothing but a showcase for gory physical effects and part of the story line may remind you of aspects of STREET TRASH (1987), one man auteur, director/screenwriter/editor/music composer/co-producer Chris LaMartina (BOOK OF LORE - 2007; PRESIDENT'S DAY - 2010; CALL GIRL OF CTHULHU - 2014, and others), keeps things moving at a quick pace and it will remind you of those gore films from the 80's, which is a good thing. There are also some terrific one-liners, especially by George Stover in his two scenes, but everyone gets a chance to shine and the acting is not bad at all. Sometimes, the film's low-budget roots show through (such as Bruce's bar only having two customers and the cases of brew have "Slacker Lager" written on them with black magic marker), but this is an inventive horror comedy (gore effects supplied by Kaleigh Browm and Jason M. Koch) that will keep your attention from beginning to end. Now this is what Kickstarter is all about! Low-budget vets George Stover (who worked with John Waters and the late Don Dohler), fast-rising actor Shawn C. Phillips (who has 92 acting credits since 2008!) and the equally fast-rising Ryan Thomas (who also cast this film) were all given Associate Producer credits. Don't get me wrong, this film is nothing ground-breaking, but it is a perfectly fine way to spend 87 minutes of your life. Filmed in the Summer of 2010, but not released on DVD until 2012. I am happy that physical effects are making a comeback in a very big way. It is music to my ears. Filmed in Baltimore, Maryland. Also starring Lauren Lakis, Virginia House, Troy Jennings, Josh Davidson, Ruby Larocca (FACES OF SCHLOCK - 2009; a four story anthology film in which Chris LaMartina directed an episode), Charlie Dreizen, Corey Holland, Lee Armstrong and A.J. Hyde. A Media Blasters DVD Release through their sub-label Guilty Pleasures. Not Rated.

WITCH STORY (1989) - Typical late-80's Italian haunted house rip-off, also known as SUPERSTITION 2, but it has very little in common with the first SUPERSTITION (1982) besides a witch being involved. It's 1932 and the townsfolk in Micanopy, Florida are up in arms that a witch (Deanna Lund) is living among them. Being proper religious witch-fearing townsfolk and all, they march to the witch's house bearing torches and weapons, stab the witch in the leg with a pitchfork, brand her neck with a red-hot poker and burn her alive as she is chained to a tree. Of course, in true burning witch fashion, she puts a curse on all the townspeople and their future family members. Watching this whole horrifying spectacle from her bedroom window is the witch's young daughter Rachel (Suzanne Law), whose blank stare could scare the shit out of a blind man. Later that night, Rachel hears her mother's voice calling her, so she breaks her attic bedroom window with her white ball and jumps out the window, her fate unknown. Cut to Florida, September 1989 and a bus full of friends, including brother Ed (Gary Kerr) and sister Carol (Michelle Vannucci), who just lost their parents six months earlier, is heading from New York City to Micanopy, Florida to stay in an old house Ed and Carol just learned they inherited. Anyone care to guess who was the former occupant? They are all met at the bus stop by Ed and Carol's cousin Simona (Nancie Sanderson), whom they have never met before. She drives them forty minutes to the house, which turns out to be in dire need of repairs. Everyone decides to stay anyway and chip in to help with repairs. Carol's best friend Susan (Amy Adams) has a run-in with Rachel and her white ball, but when black friend Gloria (Charon Butler) shows up, little Rachel disappears. After a dinner consisting of buckets of KFC, Coke and cans of Budweiser (apparently paid sponsors) and an impromptu striptease performed by a drunk Susan, the real action begins. Carol feels drawn to Rachel's attic bedroom, but Simona (who has an unhealthy interest in the occult, especially in "alternate dimensions") talks her out of it. Carol begins having nightmares and wants to leave the house, but Ed wants to stay because he has the hots for Simona ("We're not blood cousins!"). Simona, who is sleeping in Rachel's attic bedroom, has a nightmare where she brutally stabs both Ed and Carol to death and then begins to have waking visions where she views the "alternate dimension". When an ex-priest, the insane Padre Matthew (Ian Bannen), learns that the kids are staying in the house and tries his hardest to scare them the hell outta there. A possessed Susan kills her boyfriend Mike (Jeff Bankert) and then turns her attention towards Ed, while Gloria, who is also possessed, hacks Paul (Jason M. Lefkowitz) to death with a meat cleaver. Simona finds a secret passage and an important old letter, but pays for it with her life. Can Carol and Ken (Christopher Peacock) learn enough from the letter and a quite mad Padre Matthew to stop Rachel and her mother's curse?  Typical in every aspect of late-80's Italian haunted house flicks (such as GHOSTHOUSE - 1987; WITCHERY - 1988; and THE HOUSE OF WITCHCRAFT - 1989), director Alessandro Capone (who directed a series of early-90's Italian TV movies starring Bud Spencer as EXTRALARGE), who co-wrote the screenplay with Rosario Galli (Jeff Moldovan [MASTERBLASTER - 1986] gets an "adapted by" credit, probably to make the dialogue seem less "Italian"), tosses-in every haunted house cliché he can think of, including bathtubs that fill up with blood, objects that move by themselves, secret passages, people possessed by spirits, a tarot card reading that ends badly and, since this is an Italian horror film, gory deaths. Besides the meatcleaver death, there is death by chainsaw (A ridiculous scene where a possessed Susan rises from a swimming pool to cut Ed to pieces. How in the hell does a gas-powered chainsaw work underwater?); Virgil (Todd Conatser) getting his head bashed-in with a fireplace poker; Mike being thrown through a car windshield and then having his head repeatedly smashed against the car's front bumper; a priest being thrown out a window onto the hard concrete below; Susan being axed to death; and Gloria taking a shotgun blast to her stomach. The storyline doesn't make a lick of sense and everyone does the exact opposite of what any sane person would do, so if your tolerance for bullshit is set to "low", you may want to avoid WITCH STORY. Otherwise, enjoy it for what it is: an idiotic Italian horror film with some good gore. Top-billed Ian Bannen (FRIGHT - 1971) doesn't appear until the last twenty minutes. Never legitimately available on home video in the U.S.; the print I viewed was sourced from a widescreen Japanese-subtitled DVD. Not Rated.

THE WIZARD OF GORE (2007) - This "reimagining" of H.G. Lewis' THE WIZARD OF GORE (1970) finds our hero, Edmund Bigelow (Kip Pardue), stumbling into the office of Chinese doctor Chong (Brad Dourif; SONNY BOY - 1989) with his clothes covered in blood and clutching the latest (and last) edition of his weekly newspaper, The Cacaphony Gazette. As Dr. Chong and his topless female assistant apply acupuncture needles and leeches to his back, Edmund relates his sad story, which begins a week earlier. Edmund (who dresses nattily in a three-piece suit and matching fedora) and new girlfriend Maggie (Bijou Phillips; HOSTEL PART II - 2007) are attending a weird party when someone hands them two tickets to a magic show headlined by Montag The Magnificent (Crispen Glover; WILLARD - 2003; SIMON SAYS - 2008). Edmund and Maggie attend the show (the audience is a freakshow, as some are dressed as Nazis, some young women are in various state of undress and others are just plain weirdos) and the first thing they witness on-stage is a geek (Jeffrey Combs; DEAD MAN WALKING - 1987) eating a handful of maggots and the biting the head off a live rat. As one female audience member, Cayenne (Cricket DeManuel, one of several real-life "Suicide Girls" who appear in this), gets up to leave, she is stopped by Montag, who says, "Sit down bitch! You die tonight! So commands Montag The Magnificent! Ha, ha, ha!" Montag proceeds to swallow a 6-foot florescent light tube (!) and then brings Cayenne on-stage, hypnotizes her, strips her naked and then eviscerates her in front of everyone, pulling out her innards for everyone to see. The audience is shocked, until the lights go out and then comes back on with Cayenne alive and well. The audience eats it up, but it affects Edmund in a totally different way. He begins having nightmares of Cayenne (who is a stripper) dancing on-stage and spontaneously eviscerating, her guts spilling all over the dance floor. Edmund goes to Montag's show the next night, where stripper Cecelia (Amina Munster) has bear traps thrown all over her body, the last one decapitating her, but, just like the night before, when the lights come back on, she is fine and dandy and all in one piece. Edmund becomes obsessed with Montag, much to Maggie's disgust. Edmund's nightmares become more and more bizarre and violent, and when Cayenne and Cecelia end up dead in real life, both in the same manner of how they "died" on Montag's stage, he begins to dig deeper. His friend Jinky (Joshua Miller; RIVER'S EDGE - 1986, also featuring Glover), a forensics pathologist, tells Edmund that both dead girls had deadly toxins from a puffer fish in their blood system, the same toxins used in Haitian zombie rituals. Edmund researches the toxin and doesn't like what he discovers, so he brings Jinky to Montag's next show, where a girl is roasted alive. Edmund follows the girl home, finds out that she has no memory of performing in Montag's show and learns he may be responsible for starting a fire that burns the girl alive for real. Is it possible that Edmund is actually the murderer or are there far more nefarious forces at play? When Jinky is Montag's next victim on-stage (Montag shoves a broom handle covered in a towel down Jinky's throat, removes the broom handle and then quickly pulls the towel out of Jinky's throat, bringing his stomach and lungs up with the towel!), Edmund begins to learn the truth about himself, Montag and the string of murders. You can read all about it in Edmund's last edition of The Cacaphony Gazette (it comes in various versions).  More of a cyber-punk film than a horror flick, director Jeremy Kasten (THE ATTIC EXPEDITIONS - 2001; ALL SOULS DAY - 2005) places this film in a neo-noir alternate universe where everyone dresses like they live in the 40's, but carry such modern conveniences as cell phones and the backgrounds glitch like they are part of a buggy computer game. The normally manic Crispen Glover is quite restrained here as Montag (maybe a little too restrained for the film's own good), but the effects are very gory (although it's obvious some of the bloodier effects do have CGI enhancement). The script, by Zach Chassler, loses control about two thirds of the way in, when it become apparent to the viewer that Edmund has more than one loose screw in his head and the film becomes unhinged; becoming nothing but a series of disjointed scenes that really don't make much sense. While I applaud the filmmakers for not doing a straight-ahead retread of H.G. Lewis' gore film and setting it in some dream universe, I really can't recommend it because it doesn't add-up to much more than the ramblings of an insane man's mind. Still, it's better than the recent 2001 MANIACS (2005), another H.G. Lewis remake. Also starring Garz Chan, Evan Seinfield, Flux Suicide, Nixon Suicide and Kenneth Moskow. A Dimension Extreme Films DVD Release. Available in R-Rated and Unrated editions.

WOLFMAN (1979) - Shelby, North Carolina's favorite son, Earl Owensby, tries his hand at gothic horror and the results are uneven, to say the least. The film opens in 1910 with brother and sister Clement (Richard Dedmon) and Elizabeth Glasgow (Maggie Lauterer) standing at the deathbed of their Uncle Edwin (Julian Morton), when Reverend Leonard (Edward Grady) pulls out a silver dagger and stabs Edwin in the heart, killing him. All three seem pleased with the result and then send for Edwin's son, Colin Glasgow (Owensby), to come to the Glasgow Estate immediately to attend his father's funeral, but it's clear that their intentions are much more nefarious. Colin arrives by train and is greeted by family lawyer Ewan Rowe (Al Meyers) and they take a horse-drawn carriage to the family mansion, where he is greeted by Clement, Elizabeth and family butler Luther (Victor Smith). That night, while Colin is sleeping, Clement, Elizabeth and Reverend Leonard perform a satanic ritual where they transfer the "Glasgow Family Curse" into Colin's body. Now I wonder what that curse could be? After his father's funeral, Colin hooks-up with old flame Lynn Harris Randolph (Kristina Reynolds), who is recently divorced, and the romance is rekindled, much to the dismay of Lynn's father and most of the townspeople. Lynn explains to Colin that since he's been away (he's a world traveler and made his fortune in the import/export business), it's not safe to be outside at night and there have been several unsolved murders. That night, Colin has a bad nightmare where his father reaches up from his grave and grabs him on his leg, but at the reading of his father's will, where it states that the entire fortune will be left to him on the condition he spends the next thirty days at the estate, Colin grows suspicious and discovers that his father's signature on the will has been forged, which is verified by family doctor and close friend, Dr. George Tate (Sid Rancer), who tells Colin to talk to his grandmother (Helene Tryon). Grandmother Glasgow tells Colin that his father and grandfather were lycanthropes and that is why his father sent him away years ago, to protect him from the curse. Grandma also warns Colin that his cousins and Reverend Leonard are devil worshippers and if he wants proof that his father was a werewolf, he should dig his father's body up and "look at his hands", because those afflicted with werewolfism have index fingers bigger than the rest of their fingers. That night, Colin digs-up his father's body and discovers the truth (his father's index fingers could be used as blackboard pointers!), but he is attacked by a real wolf while examining the body. When he wakes up the following morning, he discovers that all his wounds have healed and his father's grave looks undisturbed. Colin tells everything to Dr. Tate, who believes Colin has just had a bad nightmare. Colin decides to leave the estate for good, but never makes it because it's a full moon tonight and Colin turns into a werewolf, killing a husband and wife in the bedroom of their home. Colin wakes up in the morning covered in blood, brings Lynn to Dr. Tate's office and confesses to the murders, so Colin agrees to be chained-up in a room in the estate's basement to convince Lynn and Dr. Tate that he is, indeed, a werewolf. Well, he does turn into a werewolf, breaks his chains and kills Luther, Clement, Elizabeth and several torch-bearing townspeople before being captured by the Sheriff (Owensby regular Brownlee Davis). Dr. Tate and Lynn try to get Reverend Tate to reverse the curse, which sets the stage for a final battle between the Reverend and werewolf Colin. Both end up dead and the curse has finally ended.  WOLFMAN is a slow, leisurely-paced period horror film directed and written by Worth Keeter (UNMASKING THE IDOL - 1986; THE ORDER OF THE BLACK EAGLE - 1986; TRAPPER COUNTY WAR - 1989) and produced by star Earl Owensby (CHALLENGE - 1973; DARK SUNDAY - 1976; SEABO - BUCKSTONE COUNTY PRISON - 1978; DOGS OF HELL - 1982) that doesn't pick up steam until after the first hour, when the werewolf makes its first appearance. The first thing you'll notice (besides Owensby's naturally hairy torso and back hair) is that the transformation scenes are very old fashioned, done in the time lapse manner of the 1941 Lon Chaney Jr. version of THE WOLF MAN. The acting, especially by Owensby, is amateurish and unconvincing (Owensby flubs several lines and was never so monotone in his delivery as he is here and that's saying a lot!) and while there are several gory scenes belying its PG-rating (Edwin's stabbing; Clement being impaled on a sword; several ripped-out throats), it's not enough to get your mind off the fact that this film is slower than molasses during a Wisconsin winter. Besides a few atmospheric sequences (the gothic setting is adequate, although a few anachronisms sneak through) and a dollop of blood, WOLFMAN will bore you to tears. Also starring Mike Allen and Charles Reynolds. Originally available on VHS by Thorn EMI Video, the film seems to have fallen into public domain and has appeared on DVD on many budget labels, including BCI Eclipse's VAULT OF HORROR 10-MOVIE compilation. Rated PG.

WRESTLEMANIAC (2006) - Six Gen-Xers drive down to Mexico in a van to make some amateur porn and end up hopelessly lost. The stumble upon a ramshackle gas station run by a dentally-challenged stranger (Irwin Keyes; LOVELY BUT DEADLY - 1981), who warns them to keep on driving when they get to the next town, because it is the burial site of legendary Mexican wrestler El Mascarado, who went crazy at the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico city and killed a whole bunch of people. Being wise-asses, they ignore the strangers warning and head for the seemingly uninhabited ghost town. When their van hits a boulder in the middle of the road and becomes disabled, the group is forced to stay in the ghost town. They begin shooting their amateur porn feature, but the hung-over Daisy (Catherine Wreford) wanders off to throw up, where she steps on some broken glass moments before someone kills her. Cameraman Steve (Jeremy Radin) is the only one that seems to be worried that they may not be alone (he spots the shadow of a strange figure in some of the video footage), but when stoner Jimbo (Zack Bennett) also disappears, the rest of the group finally falls in line. Yes, they're being stalked and killed by the spirit of El Mascarado (Rey Misterio), who legend says was created by stitching together the body parts of three of Mexico's best wrestlers in an experiment sanctioned by the President of Mexico to bring home the gold in the Olympics. It's not long before El Mascarado begins killing the rest of the group, slaughtering them in various ways and then finishing them off with his signature move; ripping off their faces, symbolizing the "unmasking" of his opponents. Steve (who is Mexican American) and Debbie (Margaret Scarborough) discover a secret laboratory in the town, where Steve translates some audiotapes that may hold the clues to defeat El Mascarado. They must unmask him in order to defeat him, but as we shall soon find out, it's not going to be all that easy. How can you unmask someone who has never been defeated?  Is this silly as hell? Sure it is. But if you want a butt-load of gore, mixed with plentiful nudity and some wrestling action, you can't go wrong with this. WRESTLEMANIAC is a short (75 minutes), professionally made slasher flick that delivers on the grue and doesn't waste much time getting right to the exploitative elements. First-time director/screenwriter Jesse Baget deserves some credit for not adhering to standard slasher elements and playing fast and loose with audience expectations on which members of the group are going to die first. The fact that group leader Alphonse (Adam Huss) is the third to die attests to this fact. His death is very hard to watch, as El Mascarado punctures his throat with a door bolt, smashes his teeth and nose on the edge of a stone step, tosses him around like a rag doll and then rips off his face in a graveyard, all in graphic close-up. There is much to recommend here, including El Mascarado's wrestling/killing room (where he keeps all the detached faces of his previous victims hanging on a wall), the over-the-top bloody effects (some of them are truly cringe-worthy) and the acting abilities of the young cast, which also includes WWE Diva Leyla Milani. Hell, this is nothing spectacular, but it is a well-made slasher flick that achieves it's goals. It's bloody as hell and quick moving. The pretty clever finale leaves this wide-open for a sequel and the closing credits contain a funny on-set rap performed by Jeremy Radin. Be aware that the Rey Misterio that stars here is not the current WWE superstar, but his uncle. An Anchor Bay Entertainment DVD Release. Not Rated.

WRONG TURN 2: DEAD END (2007) - This is a DTV sequel to the semi-popular theatrical release WRONG TURN (2003), about a family of mutant backwoods cannibals who terrorize and devour anyone who crosses their path. As Part 2 opens, starlet Kimberly (Kimberly Caldwell) gets lost while on her way to a reality TV show shoot and makes the wrong turn into Greenbrier Back County, West Virginia. She literally runs into one mutant cannibal, who chews off her lips when she stops her car to check up on him. Another inbred cannibal cuts her in two (from head to stern) with a broad axe and each cannibal drags the halves of her body away (nothing is left to the imagination, folks). It's too bad for Kimberly, because she was a scant few miles away from the reality show shoot, a SURVIVOR-like program called "Ultimate Survivalist", hosted by retired Marine Dale Murphy (Henry Rollins; FEAST - 2006), with six contestants trying their best to survive a weekend in the woods with nothing but their wits and a miniature camera attached to their heads. The woods have been set up with over three dozen hidden cameras and non-lethal booby traps, but Murphy and the contestants will soon have to deal with real lethal booby traps and the hungry cannibals themselves. The contestants include Nina (Erica Leerhsen: THE TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE - 2003), a vegan hiding a secret (Why do all cannibal films have to contain one vegan character?); Amber (Daniella Alonso; THE HILLS HAVE EYES II - 2007), a lesbian with tough survival instincts; Jake (Texas Battle; FINAL DESTINATION 3 - 2006), an ex-college football player; Jonesy (Steve Braun; PTERODACTYL - 2005), Amber's game partner, who keeps putting the moves on her even though he knows she is gay; Elena (Crystal Lowe; BLACK CHRISTMAS - 2006), a sexpot who will do anything to win the game; and Mara (Aleska Palladino), a worker on the reality show who replaces Kimberly as the final contestant when she doesn't show. The cannibal family plays it smart by first taking Murphy and the behind-the-scenes crew out of the picture first (one crew member has his throat slit and then scalped while taking a piss). Nina and Mara stumble upon the cannibal's shack, where they witness the birth of a mutant baby and Mara has a hatchet planted in her skull while escaping. The cannibals, who are highly proficient with any edged weapon (including arrows and throwing axes), then begin dispatching the rest of the contestants, beginning with Elena, who is sliced repeatedly across her back (until her spine is visible) by a jealous cannibal sister (Rorelee Tio) when she catches her brother (Clint Carelton) masturbating while gawking at Elena sunbathing (Brother and Sister make up with a big, open-mouth incestuous kiss after Sis kills Elena). Meanwhile, Murphy goes Rambo and sets out to save Nina and Jake, who are being held captive in the cannibals' home. It will take an industrial strength meat grinder to settle the score and a final stinger reveals that this is probably not the last we will see this clan (WRONG TURN 3: LEFT FOR DEAD is set for a DTV release sometime in 2009).  Though nothing remarkable, WRONG TURN 2: DEAD END is gory as hell and moves at a brisk pace, While this is nothing more than another retread of THE HILLS HAVE EYES in a forest setting, director Joe Lynch (his directorial debut) and screenwriters Turi Meyer (director of SLEEPSTALKER - 1995; CANDYMAN 3: DAY OF THE DEAD - 1999; and ALIEN EXPRESS - 2005) and Al Septien give this film a lot of bloody violence (lots of impalements, gut spilling, body explosions), carnage and black comedy moments (especially Amber, Jonesy and Jake enjoying a "barbecue", only to discover that they are eating pieces of Kimberly or when Murphy gets all dolled-up like Rambo). The film's best bit comes when Amber and Jonesy are caught in the same booby trap and are hanging upside down by their ankles. The father cannibal (Ken Kirzinger, who portrayed Jason Vorhees in FREDDY VS. JASON - 2003) decides to let his son use them as target practice and just as lesbian Amber is about to console Jonesy with a kiss, an arrow penetrates the back of Amber's head and lodges itself into Jonesy's eye, killing them both. The trick here is that director Lynch portrays the cannibal clan as a loving family, who all eat dinner together at the supper table and even say Grace before eating their meal. If it weren't for their incestuous habits and their hunger for human flesh (not to mention their mongoloid appearance), they would be no different than most of us. This is bloody, grim stuff, with some macabre humorous moments that's worth at least a rental. Also starring Matthew Currie Holmes, Wayne Robson, Ashley Earl and Jeff Scrutton. A 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment DVD Release. It's nice to see a big outfit like 20th Century Fox beginning to get involved with DTV horror (this is their first). Let's hope there are many more in the future. Unrated, and for good reason.

WRONG TURN 3: LEFT FOR DEAD (2009) - I'm a sucker for inbred cannibal flicks, which is why I liked the original, theatrically-released WRONG TURN (2003) and it's first DTV sequel, WRONG TURN 2: DEAD END (2007), a fast-paced and gory flick that mixed cannibal and reality TV genres to good effect. PART 3 kicks off in grand fashion, with two kayaking couples traveling down a river and stopping for a pot break. Enter mutated cannibal Three Finger (Borislav Iliev), as he shoots one of the girls in her breast with an arrow (it also pierces her boyfriend's hand as he's feeling her up!) and then finishes her off with another arrow through the back of her head and her right eye popping out of its socket, stuck on the arrow's tip (which the giggling Three Finger eats like it was a piece of chocolate). Three Finger kills the two guys, one with a spiked pole through the mouth and the other with a wire booby trap, which cuts him into three pieces (an obvious CGI effect, but watching Three Finger sticking his face into the bloody offal of the shredded body will put you off lunch for several days). The only one to survive is Alex (Janet Montgomery; THE HILLS RUN RED - 2009), but we will have to wait a while to see how she copes. The film then switches to West Virginia's Grafton Penitentiary, where guards Nate (Tom Frederic; BLOOD TRAILS - 2006) and Walter (Chucky Venn) must escort notorious prisoner Chavez (Tamer Hassain) and other violent cons, including skinhead Floyd (Gil Kolirin), to another prison. Only Nate knows that the prisoner chained to Chavez, Willy (Christian Contreras), is actually an undercover U.S. Marshal who believes that Chavez, with Floyd's help, is planning an escape during the bus trip. Since Nate was born and bred in the area, he takes the bus on the Old Mill Road to avoid an escape attempt, but it puts them in prime cannibal country (Ah, West Virginia. Home of coal mines and Slavic-looking flesh-eating mutant cannibals!). Of course, Three Finger spots the bus and forces it over an embankment with his pickup truck and the foot chase is on. Three Finger and his cannibal friend, Three Toe, begin slaughtering the prisoners in various ways, as Chavez gets the upper hand and makes Nate and a badly injured Walter his prisoners. With Nate as their guide, the group head for safety and run into Alex, who warns them about the cannibals (Not only is she a little late in that department, she really should worry about Floyd, who wants her to "sit and spin" on his lap!). The rest of the film is a series of gory set pieces, as the prisoners find an abandoned armored car full of money (and become greedy). Chavez shoots Walter in the head and then cuts Three Toe's head off and impales it on a pole for Three Finger to find. Willy is the next to die when he has his face cut off by a scythe booby trap (Chavez and Floyd cut off Willy's legs to free them from their leg shackles!). Will Nate and Alex escape, since they not only have to worry about Three Finger, they also have to deal with Chavez and Floyd's brutal tactics? Stay tuned, it's about to get bloody.  As a gore flick, WRONG TURN 3 delivers in spades, as limbs are hacked off, necks are sliced, booby traps are triggered, brains are eaten, bodies are impaled and flesh is devoured. Too bad director Declan O'Brien (who directed three Syfy original movies in 2008: ROCK MONSTER, CYCLOPS and MONSTER ARK) and screenwriter Connor James Delaney throw all logic out the window, making every plot device in this film seem forced and outright ridiculous. Sure, the film is bloody as hell, but without a good storyline, all the film has to offer is a series of gory killings (some done with CGI enhancement, including Willy's face removal) with characters you don't give two shits about, so when they are killed, the viewer really doesn't care. As far as killer cannibal flicks go, WRONG TURN 3: LEFT FOR DEAD is minor stuff, but if you like gore for gore's sake, you may want to give it a look. Me? I'd rather have at least a couple of characters I care about to go along with all the grue. You'll find none of that here, although the triple-cross finale did catch me by surprise and sets it up for the inevitable Part 4. Filmed in Bulgaria around the same time as THE HILLS RUN RED. Followed by WRONG TURN 4: BLOODY BEGINNINGS (2011), which is a prequel of sorts that tells the origins of Three Finger and his cannibal family, WRONG TURN 5: BLOODLINES (2012) and the final film, WRONG TURN 6: FINAL RESORT (2014), all of which I will be reviewing shortly. Also starring Tom McKay, Mike Straub, Emma Clifford, Todd Jenson, Louise Cliffe and Bill Moody. A Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment DVD Release. Unrated.

WTF! (2017) - In this DTV horror film, Rachel (Callie Ott) was the "final girl" left alive after watching her friends being slaughtered by some unknown madman three years ago. The killer was never found. Rachel and her college friends want to decide what to do for Spring Break and friend Jacob (Benjamin Norris - 13/13/13 - 2013) suggests they go to a refurbished cabin in the woods that his Uncle fixed up , but never uses (He "forgets " to tell them that his Uncle disappeared in the woods and was never found). To get to the regular modern horror film conventions Jacob tells them there is no cable, internet or cell phone service in the area, but there is electricity, so the stupid girls decide to go anyway since the cabin has a built-in pool. (Is there anything such as a "second final girl"? I guess Laurie Strode could be consider one after battling Michael Myers in HALLOWEEN [1978] and HALLOWEEN II [1981]) Actually, the entire film is one big flashback, as Rachel is telling the story of what happened at the cabin to two detectives in an interrogation room.  But you don't have to be a genius to figure out this film's "surprise reveal" to figure out who the killer is. On their way to the cabin, they stop at the last convenience store before they hit the woods (name me one horror film of this type where the same thing doesn't happen). An old man behind the counter warns the kids not to go where they are heading and doesn't tell them why. They all go anyway and ignore the old man's advice (Rachel leaves her credit card behind which leads to the funniest scene in the film). Most of the girls and guys on this trip are sex-crazed and once they see the cabin and the pool (The inside of the cabin looks like it was filmed in a normal house and what person in their right mind would put a beautiful built-in pool in the middle of the woods? Think about the problems.). Rachel's Paris Hilton-looking friend Bonnie (Andrea Hunt; AWAKEN THE SHADOWMAN - 2017) strips off her bikini and jumps into the pool which causes all the guys and other girls (besides Rachel) to do the same thing (Speaking of Paris Hilton, the despicable gossip-mongering, wrecker-of-lives Perez Hilton [Real Name: Mario Lavandeira] puts in a 10 second cameo at a party at the beginning of the film where he has a line and then pukes. He makes me puke! Let's just say as an actor, he is a good puker.) Bevan (Adam Foster) has his throat cut while he is playing video games and Rachel sees it. She runs to her friends to tell them what she saw, but when they all come back, Bevan's body is missing. It is at this time that Jacob tells everyone about his missing Uncle; he supposedly died, but his body was never found. Sam (Johnny James Fiore) is the next to be found dead after making love to Lisa (Sarah Agor - HATCHET II - 2010)). The killer cuts his ball's off and throws them on his dead body. It should be noted that Sam is/was Rachel's boyfriend. Rachel disappears and the Bonnie has her face burned off with an aerosol can of hair spray and a lighter. We then watch Toby (Nick Reilly) kill Lisa with an ax. Rachel reveals to Jacob that Toby is actually the killer, but no one knows who Toby is. Rachel tells Jacob that she is actually Toby, as we watch flashbacks (flashbacks within a flashback?) of Rachael killing everyone, while she imagines she is Toby, her non-existent brother. Rachel kills Jacob by slitting open his stomach and pulling out his intestines. The film ends on that note, with the male interrogating Detective calling her a "crazy fucking bitch". The closing credits play over pre-production sketches showing how the cast will die and Rachel's eventual fate and, believe me, it would have been a much better movie. Exposing Rachel as the killer is a no-brainer. I literally mean you could be born without a brain and still figure it out. Luckily, there is plenty of female eye candy to go around in or out of their clothes. As far as the special makeup effects go, only the killings of Bonnie and Jacob register; all the other deaths are done in the dark and are impossible to see. If this is 2017's idea of a horror film (it is only 80 minutes long), we are all in trouble. Director/co-screenwriter Peter Herro (His first feature film, although like most new filmmakers today, he has directed plenty of shorts) does absolutely nothing here to build suspense or create a sense of terror. This is basic stalk and slash stuff, but without the usual bloody kills (except for Jacob's). The screenplay (co-written by Christopher Centanni & Adam Buchalter) follows all the genre conventions, but fails miseraably at making us understand why no one suspects Rachel when she went through the same thing three years earlier. It would take a psychiatrist five minutes to diagnose Rachel's multiple personality disorder, yet the rest of the cast don't even care. And that is why this film burns and crashes with the viewer, Ignore all the positive reviews on IMDb, because it is apparent they were written by someone who worked on the film. A Midnight Releasing DVD Release. This film also features Shawn C. Phillips (ASSAULT OF THE SASQUATCH - 2009; GIRLS GONE DEAD - 2012) in a cameo scene in a pool at the beginning of the film. By the looks of him, he lost a lot of weight (Has lost over 535 pounds since June 2014). Not Rated, but only because it wasn't submitted to the MPAA (a frequent DTV practice to fool customers into thinking they are about to see the bloodiest movie ever made). If it were rated, it would probably get an R-Rating.

ZOLTAN: HOUND OF DRACULA (1977) - They sure don't make 'em like this anymore. If that a good or bad thing depends on your state of mind. I was laughing hysterically at this one, although I doubt that was what director Albert Band (I BURY THE LIVING - 1958; ROBOT WARS - 1993) was shooting for. In some unknown Slavik country (Transylvania, I suppose), soldiers are doing some underground blasting and accidently uncover a tomb which contains Dracula's decendents. A soldier is posted at the site for the night when a tremor shakes loose two coffins. The soldier pulls the stake out of a draped figure and it turns out to be Zoltan, DRACULA'S DOG! (it was released to theaters under this title). The dog puts the bite on the soldier and then opens the other coffin. The dog pulls the stake out of the corpse and it turns out to be Veidt Smith (the unmistakable Reggie Nalder, "Albino" in MARK OF THE DEVIL - 1970), a "half vampire" who can walk in daylight. He searches for the last remaining decendent of Dracula, a family man in California named Michael Drake (Michael Pataki, who played a bloodsucker in GRAVE OF THE VAMPIRE - 1972), in hopes of turning him into a vampire. Veidt takes a ship to L.A. with Zoltan and his coffin in a crate. Not far behind Veidt is Inspector Branco (Jose Ferrer), a cop from the Old Country who is out to stop Veidt and the vampire canine. Drake, his wife, two kids and two dogs with a "litter of puppies" (actually two) go on a camping trip in their RV and are soon set upon by Zoltan and Veidt. Zoltan first bites one of the puppies, which Drake and his kids find dead and bury it. Zoltan then bites the two adult dogs and a hound dog owned by a couple of hunters camped out nearby. Zoltan then attacks a hiker, tearing him apart limb from limb. Zoltan then attacks Drake but the cricifix on his neck drives the vampire dog away. Inspector Branco arrives on the scene and explains what is happening to Drake. Drake sends his wife, kids and remaining puppy away and, with the help of Inspector Branco, defeats Veidt (stake through the heart) and Zoltan (falls off a cliff onto a picket fence!). The finale is a real laugh riot as the puppy that was bitten is seen chewing on a decapitated rabbit, bearing it's bloody infant fangs and glowing eyes for the camera. Where to begin? First, it's hard to say which is worse: The incessant close-ups of Reggie Nalder's face or the frequent shots of Zoltan's bloody fangs with dubbed in howling and growling noises. Both are equally cringe-inducing and rib-tickling. The best part is when the dogs are bitten. It's obviously a dog puppet biting their necks but that's not the funniest part. After they are bitten, they all turn a sickly gray color! There's also a really funny vampire dog attack at a shack where Drake and Branco are hiding out, where the pack destroy the shack and Zoltan chews through the roof! Another funny scene is where Drake outruns the vampire canine pack and locks himself in a convertible! That should keep them out. You have to look at this film as camp to fully appreciate it otherwise you'll just be shaking your head in disbelief. I enjoyed it for all the obvious wrong reasons. At least I liked it. Written by Frank Ray Perilli, who is also responsible for MANSION OF THE DOOMED (1975, which Pataki directed) and LASERBLAST (1978). Also starring Jan Shutan, Simmy Bow, Libby Chase, John Levin and Roger Pancake. Originally released on VHS by Thorn EMI and now available on DVD from Anchor Bay Entertainment. Rated R.

ZOMBIE (1979) - What can I say about this movie that you probably haven't heard? For the sake of those unfamiliar with this film, I'll give you a little plot synopsis. A boat sails into New York Harbor, seemingly devoid of passengers. The harbor patrol boards the boat and one guy gets a hefty part of his neck bitten off by an overweight zombie. The zombie is dispatched by gunfire and falls into the water. The dead harbor patrol officer is taken in for an autopsy. A girl (Tisa Farrow) , who is the daughter of the man who owned the boat, and a newspaper reporter (Ian McCulloch) go to an island in the Caribbean where her father was last seen alive, to solve the mystery. It seems that the island is cursed and the dead are coming back to life. A doctor on the island (Richard Johnson) knows how to stop this plague; shoot 'em in the head. (Sound familiar?) It's not long before the island is full of the walking dead and everyone that is alive is fighting for their lives. Only Ms. Farrow and Mr. McCulloch come out alive and they lock a zombie on board their boat as proof as they sail back to New York. Too late, as New York is full of the walking dead, started by the bitten harbor patrol cop. This film is a notch above the rest of the Italian zombie pics. The photography is sharp, the make-up and gore effects are quite convincing (and graphic!), and the acting is above par this time around. Many critics blasted late director Lucio Fulci for "borrowing" other directors' ideas and styles. Maybe he did, but he had his own style which was quite unique and stood out.  One scene is so outstanding, I doubt I'll ever forget it. It takes place after our hero crashes the jeep and the survivors have to flee on foot through the jungle to escape from the zombies. They stumble upon an ancient burial ground of Spanish Conquistadors, which proceed to rise from the grave. It's all very creepy and atmospheric. One zombie even rises from the standing position! Let's also not forget the scene of the wood shard going through an eyeball. I still squirm when that scene comes up. This is one of those films that I could watch over and over without ever growing tired of it. The blood doesn't begin to flow until half the movie has passed, but it is never boring. As close a tribute to George Romero as you can get, with a lot of originality thrown in (even the "zombie vs. shark" sequence was used in part of a TV commercial!). ZOMBIE, originally released by Wizard Video on VHS, is available on VHS and DVD from Anchor Bay and a really shitty VHS print from T-Z Video. Also available on DVD from Media Blasters/Shriek Show in a 2-DVD set under the title ZOMBI 2 (the title used for the film overseas). Blue Underground also offers the film on DVD & Blu-Ray in a single disc or double-disc set. Blue Underground also released the film on 4K Blu-Ray in three separate covers. Also featuring Al Cliver, Stefania D'Amario, Auretta Gay, Franco Fantasia and Olga Karlatos as the poor woman who has her eye impaled on a sharp wooden shard. Fulci has a brief cameo as McCulloch's newspaper editor. Unrated.

ZOMBIE 5: KILLING BIRDS (1987) - Before I get to the review, let me give you the confusing history of the "ZOMBIE" franchise. George Romero's DAWN OF THE DEAD (1978) was known as ZOMBI(E) in Italy and other European countries (in a different cut than the U.S. theatrical version). When Lucio Fulci's ground-breaking ZOMBIE (1979) reached our shores, it was known as ZOMBI 2 in Italy. Then a series of unrelated latter-day Italian zombie films followed; ZOMBI 3 (1987), directed by Fulci and co-directed by Bruno Mattei & Claudio Fragasso when Fulci suffered a stroke and couldn't continue; ZOMBIE 4: AFTER DEATH (1988), which was a retitling of the Italian film AFTER DEATH ("Oltre la morte"), a tale of voodoo shot in the Philippines and directed by Fragasso; and, finally, this film, a retitling of the Italian film KILLING BIRDS (it's the on-screen title of the print I viewed). NOTE: VHS Labels T-Z Video, Ace Video & Edde Entertainment released a bunch of numbered ZOMBIE films, which were retitled, but they have nothing to do with this franchise. Alright, confused? Now, on with the review:
     A soldier returns home to Louisiana from the Vietnam War to discover his wife has shacked-up with another man. He finds the man sleeping next to his wife in his bed, pulls out his Army knife and slices the man's throat while he is sleeping. When his wife wakes up and discovers what he has done, she tries to run away, but he also slices her throat. He then kills his wife's parents, who are holding a baby (he kills the father by throwing the knife dead-center into his forehead and cuts the mother's throat). He does not kill the baby, though, and good thing, because the baby is his, which he never knew. The soldier is also a bird lover (his house is full of caged and uncaged birds of every type) and, in a case of very bad luck, the soldier has his eyes pecked out by his own birds (I guess they didn't like him going off to war!).
     Years pass, as we are then introduced to a group of college students who are going on an expedition to locatethe ivory-billed woodpecker, a species of bird that is about to go extinct. The college students, Anne (Lara Wendel), Steve (Timothy W. Watts), Mary (Leslie Cummins), Paul (James Villemaire), Jennifer (Lin Gathright), Rob (James Sutterfield) & Brian (Sal Maggiore Jr.), go to the isolated house of Dr. Fred Brown (Robert Vaughn) since he was the last personto "see" the said near-extinct woodpecker. They soon discover that Dr. brown is blind as a bat (His eye sockets are hideously  mangled and it doesn't take a rocket scientist to realize that he is the murderous soldier). It seems that Dr. Brown can identify any species of bird by the sound it makes, but when he hands Steven some mysterious papers, it makes us wonder what he is really up to (Steven takes the papers and refuses to tell Anne, who is also a reporter, what is in them, but it doesn't take a genius to come up with the answer).
    The group continue on their quest (lots of stock footage of birds flying; many species which cannot be found in this area of the U.S.!) and they come upon a rusted pickup truck (which we saw was not rusted in the film's opening), which contains the body of a rotting corpse. Rather than going to the police, the group continues on their trek and come upon the soldier's abandoned house. It is full of empty, rusted bird cages and they decide to stay there for the night. Steve then begins having visions, where the house is like brand new. The rusted bird cages are now bright and shiny and full of birds. He also sees that one of the bedrooms has bloody sheets and the adjoining bathroom sink is full of blood. Steve also imagines that Dr. Brown is in the house, a female zombie is calling his name and Jennifer is cricified to a wall, her hands impaled with railroad spikes. it doesn't take a genius to know that these aren't visions at all. They are memories from Steve's infancy.
     It's not long before the college kids are being picked-off one-by-one. Jennifer has her head bashed-in when a zombie grabs her hair and slams her noggin into a wall over and over. Could her death have something to do with a newspaper she found that was dated March 29, 1965 (the date Steven was born)? Brian is the next to die when he is set on fire and runs into the woods (Remember: Only you can prevent forest fires!). The group decide to leave when Mary discovers Jennifer's bloody body and their van suddenly appears at the house. Rob tries to hotwire the van (Brian had the keys) as zombies approach. Mary is killed when she is pulled out of the van's back window and the skin on her neck stretches until it snaps, like cheese on a pizza (the film's grossest, but not bloodiest, effect). They all run back into the house when escape is impossible.  Rob is killed when his necklace gets caught in the spinning gears of a generator and it nearly decapitates him (He does lose two fingers to the gears when he tries to free himself).
     Their laptop computer (one of those old bricks shaped like a suitcase) suddenly says on screen "Welcome Home, Steve" and the group are puzzled (this was before wi-fi). A zombie attacks Anne & Steve, but they get away and hide in the attic with Paul. Paul doesn't fare too well when a zombie grabs his head and pulls him through a hole in the roof (an effect that was previously done in Joe D'Amato's ANTHROPOPHAGUS - 1980; I don't know if this was intentional, but the majority of deaths here have to do with head violence). Dr. Brown shows up at the house and calls Steve "son" (He also tells Steve this about his blindness: "How can you be afraid when you live in eternal darkness?"). He tells Steve and Anne to leave the house  and we see thousands of birds descend on the house as Dr. Brown screams. THE END.
    This is a slow and unremarkable Italian horror film, directed by Claudio Lattanzi, using the pseudonym "Claude Milliken", his only directorial effort (He was First Assistant Director on films such as Michele Soavi's STAGEFRIGHT [1987], the horrid INTERZONE [1987] and Umberto Lenzi's GHOSTHOUSE [1987]. It was a good year for him!). Some sources list Joe D'Amato as an uncredited director (He was the producer of this film). I don't know whether that is true, but it would explain the attic death. The screenplay, by Daniele Stroppa (WITCHERY - 1988), makes very little sense (How does a decades-old unused generator suddenly start with one pull? How does the blind Dr. Brown arrive at his old home, which is miles away from his new home?) and the surprise "reveals" are telegraphed very early on. But it is the awful acting which sinks this film. It's not surprising that many of the "actors" who appear as the college kids never went on to do anything else, especially Timothy W. Watts as Steve. His emoting is laughable as he tries to act while speaking in monotone, even when he is scared. It is obvious that Robert Vaughn was only hired for a couple of days shooting as his screen time is minimal. Vaughn has made some stinkers in his life (try watching THE LUCIFER COMPLEX - 1979), but not as bad as this.
     It comes as no surprise that this never got a legal VHS release. The review is based on the Media Blaster/Shriek Show DVD (no Blu-Ray at the time of this review), which is short on extras. Just a trailer and a short interview with Robert Vaughn (who passed away in 2016), who has precious few memories of appearing in this, but he has high praise for Roger Corman. He talks about his early appearance in Corman's TEENAGE CAVE MAN (1958), where Corman's quick shooting schedule got him seriously hurt on several occasions. He also talks about appearing in Corman's BATTLE BEYOND THE STARS (1980) and TRANSYLVANIA TWIST (1989), the latter film he said he starred in due to his young daughter wanting him to appear as a bad guy (a funny bad guy) in a horror film. A nice, little interview which shows that Vaughn appreciated in appearing in low budget films. This is also available in Media Blaster's THE ZOMBIE PACK, where this is part of a three-film zombie set, the other two films being the third and fourth entries in the franchise. Also starring Brigitte Paillet, Nona Paillet and  Ellis Paillet as Dr. Brown's ill-fated wife and in-laws.  Not Rated. UPDATE: Now available on Blu-Ray from those fine folks at Vinegar Syndrome.

ZOMBIE HIGH (1987) - Pretty slow teenager-in-peril film originally known as THE SCHOOL THAT ATE MY BRAIN. Lovely Virginia Madsen (CANDYMAN - 1992) essays the role of Andrea Miller, one of the first girls to be enrolled in what once was an all-boys boarding school. The science teacher (Richard Cox; THE VINDICATOR - 1986) becomes immediately enamored with her, much to the consternation of her boyfriend (James Wilder; PREY OF THE CHAMELEON - 1992). It turns out that the science teacher, along with all of the faculty, are immortal. They need a daily injection of a serum made from a part of a human brain to keep them from growing old. They get this serum from the students, whom they kidnap at night. The piece of the brain that is taken away is replaced by a crystal, which makes the students obedient and unemotional. Andrea discovers their secret after witnessing extreme behavioral changes in her newfound friends, including her roommate Sherilyn Fenn (TWIN PEAKS [1990 - 1991], MERIDIAN: KISS OF THE BEAST [1990]). The crystal controls the students by way of piped-in musak, which keeps them in a zombie-like state (Jesus, musak would keep even the most staid person in a zombie-like state!). Cox decides to help Andrea because she reminds him of his long-dead wife. Along with her boyfriend, she destroys the faculty's supply of serum, turning the teachers into shriveled up corpses. Then they replace the musak cassette with a heavy metal song titled "Kiss My Butt" that burns out the crystals in all of the students' heads. It even destroys the ones in the former students' heads, including the President of the United States! The story is fine, but the execution is dull. No nudity and very little blood make bad exploitation fare. A waste of talent. This was director Ron Link's only film credit (he passed away in 1999). A Cinema Group Home Video Release. Rated R.

ZOMBIE NIGHTMARE (1986) - When two punks try to rape a black girl, family man Bill Washington (John Fasano) steps in to break it up and gets stabbed to death in front of his wife and young son Tony. Years pass and Tony (Jon Mikl Thor) is a devoted muscleheaded mama's boy and health food nut. He foils a robbery at the neighborhood grocery store, only to get run over and killed by five drunk punks in a car. Tony's mother has Molly Mokembe (Manuska), the woman who Tony's father saved from the rape years earlier and who is a voodoo priestess, turn Tony into a zombie (what a good mom!). He will stay a zombie until he avenges all those who who took his life, then he will rest in eternal peace. Zombie Tony rises from his coffin, grabs his favorite baseball bat and gets down to business. Tony gets his first two victims at the gym, where he snaps one guy's neck and crushes his girlfriend's head with his trusty bat. Detective Frank Sorrell (Frank Dietz) is assigned to the case and hasn't got a clue where to begin, which doesn't please Capt. Churchman (Adam West), who seems to have more invested in this case than he's letting on. Tony then impales the next guy with his bat while he is raping a girl in an alley (When the coroner sees the guy with the baseball bat sticking out of his stomach, he says, "Christ on a crutch, Frank!"). The last two gang members, Bob (Allan Fisher) and Amy (Tia Carrere, in a really bad career choice), decide to stick together, while we learn that Churchman was one of the two punks involved in Tony's death. Tony kills Bob by smashing his head against a car and crushes Amy's head against a window. Frank is close behind and chases Tony back to his final resting place (his work is done). Churchman kidnaps Molly and brings her to the graveyard. He shoots Tony in the back and then shoots Molly in the chest. He's about to shoot Frank when Tony's father rises from his grave and drags Churchman down to the pits of Hell. Everyone is avenged at last.  It's hard to describe in mere words how dreadful this film really is. Non-directed by Jack Bravman (who directed the female vigilante film JANIE [1970] and the simply horrible NIGHT OF THE DRIBBLER [1990] and usually produces films such as THE CARPENTER [1987], which was directed by David Wellington, ZOMBIE NIGHTMARE's scripter), the film plods along at such a snail's pace, you'll swear the hands on your watch are moving backwards. I'm still trying to figure out how Churchman becomes captain of the police force in the town where he murdered Tony's father years earlier. Surely Tony's mother recognizes him, right? My brain hurts. Whoever told musician Jon Mikl Thor (ROCK 'N' ROLL NIGHTMARE - 1987) he could act should be arrested for impersonating a talent agent. Thor makes the most unconvincing zombie you'll ever see as he lumbers along like one of those musclemen who exercise too much and can't walk normally (imagine if you have a load of shit in your pants and had to walk for a mile). Frank Dietz (THE JITTERS - 1988) is the closest this film comes to decent acting, as Adam West (who appeared in all kinds of crap during the 80's and 90's like OMEGA COP [1990] and MAXIM XUL [1990]) sleepwalks through his role and the beautiful Tia Carrere (HOLLOW POINT - 1995) is given nothing to do but scream. The gore and nudity are non-existant and everything else about the film looks to have been done on the cheap, such as when Frank talks on his police radio and they didn't bother to loop a reply voice on the other end. The best thing about the film is the soundtrack, which consists of songs from Motorhead, Pantera, Girlschool, Virgin Steele, Fist and, of course, Thor. John Fasano, who cameos as Tony's father and would later go on to direct the craptacular trio ROCK 'N' ROLL NIGHTMARE (1987), BLACK ROSES (1988) and THE JITTERS (1988), was assistant director here. Also starring Linda Singer, Shawn Levy, Hamish McEwen and Francesca Bonacorba. A New World Video VHS Release. Also available on widescreen DVD from Scorpion Releasing and Blu-Ray from Code Red as an exclusive for Screen Archives Entertainment. Rated R.

ZOMBIES: THE BEGINNING (2007) - This is late Italian exploitation director Bruno Mattei's final film (directed using the pseudonym "Vincent Dawn", one of more than twenty aliases he used in his long career) and, while it pales when compared to his 70's & 80's output (CAGED WOMEN - 1982; RATS: NIGHT OF TERROR - 1983), it still stands out heads-and-shoulders when compared to his later films, including CANNIBAL HOLOCAUST: THE BEGINNING (2003) and THE TOMB (2004). Meanwhile, his WIP flick, THE JAIL: THE WOMEN'S HELL (2006), is supposed to be the best (and sleaziest) of his final output (and, I'm happy to say, it is). This Philippines-lensed horror film, a sequel to Mattei's 2006 zombie flick, ISLAND OF THE LIVING DEAD (but with a few cosmetic changes), begins where ISLAND left off: the rescue of sole survivor Sharon (Yvette Yzon), who, after waking up in a hospital (where she has nightmares of turning into a zombie and munching on a nurse), relates a story about an uncharted island that contains hordes of the living dead to the unbelieving insurance representatives of the sunken salvage ship The Dark Star, of which Sharon was a crew member before it exploded after a zombie attack. No one believes her story and six months pass before she is contacted by Paul Barker (Paul Holme), a drug company representative, who wants her to join a rescue team to investigate the disappearance of a crew of scientists sent to the island several weeks earlier to bring back some zombies for further study, in hopes of creating new drugs to prolong life. A now-Buddhist Sharon eventually agrees (she's got nothing to lose, since she's still haunted by nightmares and unemployable in the outside world) and joins a small group of heavily armed mercenaries as they head to the island in a submarine (cue the stock footage!). Once on the island, Sgt. Zamura (Robert B. Johnson), the leader of the mercs, discovers that the missing scientists' base of operations is deserted, but fully operational. The mercs find a warehouse full of eaten body parts and then a laboratory lined with cages containing zombies and aborted baby zombie fetuses. What kind of experiments were the scientists performing? It's not long before everyone on the island will find out the answer and the mercs' numbers begin to dwindle, thanks to attacks by zombie babies (actually Filipino dwarves in disguise!) and a swarm of mutated zombies. While Barker, Sharon and Capt. Jurgens (James Paolleli; STRANGLEHOLD - 1994) monitor the situation from the Control Room, it becomes quite obvious that Barker knows more about this situation than he letting on, as more mercs become zombie chow and Sharon pulls a Ripley, commandeers a vehicle and tries to rescue them. The remainder of the film details Sharon's battles against the zombies and the eventual uncovering of Barker's true reasons for wanting to come to the island. Sharon makes a shocking discovery in the bowels of the base (a queen zombie spitting out babies like Pez and a giant brain controlling it all!) and uses her trusty flame-thrower to destroy it all.  This zombie flick is a not-so-thinly veiled rip-off of James Cameron's ALIENS (1986), substituting zombies for aliens. Many of the sequences are copied verbatim, including the birth of a baby zombie clearly patterned on the baby aliens bursting from the stomachs of their human hosts and the character of Barker representing Paul Reiser's corrupt representative Burke in ALIENS. Barker even locks Sharon in a lab with a bunch of hungry zombies, mimicking the scene of Ripley locked in the lab with a face-hugger. If you can ignore all the similarities (and that's a big if, because a drinking game can be played spotting the ALIENS homages and you'd be smashed after the first twenty minutes), the bad acting, the horrendous English dubbing and dialogue (Typical exchange between two mercenaries: #1: "Now we're in deep shit!" #2: "Shut your fucking mouth!"), you may find yourself enjoying all the decently-done gore, which includes gut-munching, a body being torn in half, appendages being yanked-off, decapitations and exploding heads. This is by no means a good film, but it is probably Bruno Mattei's best in the crop of films he directed in the new millennium. I know that's not saying much, but that's all we have now that Mattei shuffled off to the Great Beyond shortly after finishing this (There's a short tribute to the frail-looking Mattei during the closing credits). Filipino staple Jim Gaines (also the Production Coordinator here) puts in a cameo as a giant zombie. Also starring Diana Croyston, Mike Vergel and Gerald Acho. While this has yet to find an American distributor as of this writing (I'm sure it will sooner or later if 20th Century Fox doesn't sue producer/co-scripter Gianni Paolucci for plagiarism), it can easily be obtained on the Internet on German DVD from company KSM in a widescreen English-dubbed print. Now available on widescreen DVD for the first time in the U.S. from InterVision Picture Corp., an offshoot of Severin Films. Unrated.

ZOMBIE WARS (2007) - Ever since his debut directorial effort, the shot-on-video horror flick SLEDGEHAMMER in 1984, it was apparent that David A. Prior was a unique talent. Unfortunately, unique is not necessarily associated with quality, because Prior was responsible for some of the lowest-budget and lower-tier action, horror and science fiction films of the 80's & 90's, including KILLER WORKOUT (1986), MANKILLERS (1987), RAPID FIRE (1989) and MUTANT SPECIES (1995). While it is true that Prior managed to sneak in an enjoyable film every now and then, the truth is that for every winner like FUTURE FORCE (1989) or THE LOST PLATOON (1991), we had to put up with awfulness like NIGHT WARS (1988), JUNGLE ASSAULT (1989) and WHITE FURY (1990). Some day, there will be a detailed account (whether it be a book or magazine article) on Prior's interesting life (he was one of the co-founders of Action International Pictures [the "other" A.I.P.], which littered video shelves with every type of cheap genre film from the mid-80's to the early-90's), but it is nice to see that he is still swinging for the fences with this truly crappy (but strangely watchable) combination of action and zombie genres. Fifty years ago, some unknown phenomenon caused millions of dead people to rise from their graves and begin feasting on the living (like most modern zombie films, these are fast-moving undead, not shuffling, slow-as-molasses zombies). Unlike most zombies of yore, these are not your typical mindless undead; they are organized and raise humans from infancy to be used as banquets at a later date. The film opens with two brothers, David (Adam Stuart) and Brian (Jim Marlow), saving a bunch of women being led by a group of zombies to one of their base camps. David and Brian dispatch the zombies, either by shooting them in the head or by machete decapitation and are quick with a witty quip after each killing (David rips one zombie's arm off and says to his brother, "Need a hand?" Now that's quality screenwriting!). David and Brian belong to a small military group led by The General (Kristi Renee Pearce) and their job is to free as many human slaves as they can, re-educate them (many of the human slaves have been raised by the zombies since birth and have never heard English before) and teach them how to fight. David falls for Star (Alissa Koenig), one of the women he and Brian just saved, and when their camp is overrun by zombies (plenty of gut-munching on display here), David and Star become separated from their party and are captured by the zombies. They are brought to "The Farm", where the zombies (who actually have a political hierarchy) mate humans for food and David learns quickly not to talk in front of the zombies (another captive soldier who does speak is eaten alive). David meets Sliver (Jonathan Badeen), a soldier that has been at The Farm for five years (and hasn't spoken a word of English since his capture) and they come up with a plan for escape, but David doesn't fully trust Sliver (and for good reason). It is revealed that Sliver is working for a human council that is in collusion with the zombies for reasons not yet made clear. While The General and Brian (who are falling in love) search for David, they come up against a group of zombies carrying crates full of tin cans containing fresh vegetables and meat. Since it is clear that this is not for zombie consumption (whoever heard of a zombie vegetarian?) and all the tin cans are brand new, the questions soon become: Who is supplying this to the zombies and why? You would have to be as brain-dead as a 300 year-old zombie not to figure it out. Sliver turns good guy and defies the council's orders (they want him to kill David) and he spills everything he knows to David. With David and Sliver working from the inside and Brian and The General working from the outside, the zombies and their human allies don't stand a chance.  While the gore comes at a fast and furious pace and the acting at least tries to be earnest (although Jonathan Badeen seems to have learned his craft by watching too much Jack Nicholson), director/screenwriter/co-producer David A. Prior can't seem to make up his mind whether he wants to make a horror film or an action film. While that would not normally be a problem (the remake of DAWN OF THE DEAD [2004] did it with much gusto), Prior's screenplay is unsure or more to the point, insecure, about where it stands. There are many "What The Fuck?!?" sequences on view, such as human zombie ally George (Billy Hayes, who also plays the "Zombie King") painting his house red, while bitching and moaning to his tied-up zombie parents; David suffering the same fate as the hero in the original NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD (1968); or The General playing a very unfunny practical joke on Brian, you'll be wondering what Prior was smoking when he wrote the script. Prior shot ZOMBIE WARS (also known as WAR OF THE LIVING DEAD) on HD Digital Video, so it looks crisp and colorful, especially the too-numerous-to-count gunshots to the head, gut-munching, neck-biting, decapitations (the only obvious use of CGI in the film) and the weirdly effective zombie makeups. Worth a viewing just for all the wrongheaded twists and turns. Also starring Loretta Norton, James Warnock, Danielle Jacobs, Steven Stewart and Anthony Contreras. An American World Pictures DVD Release. Not Rated. UPDATE: David A. Prior passed away of cancer on August 16, 2015 at the age of 59.
